metadata.title: Coronavirus occurrence and transmission over 8 years in the HIVE cohort of households in Michigan

abstract.text: As part of the Household Influenza Vaccine Evaluation (HIVE) study, acute respiratory 5 infections (ARI) have been identified in children and adults over 8 years.
Annually, 890 to 1441 individuals were followed and contacted weekly to report ARIs.
Specimens collected during illness were tested for human coronaviruses (HCoV) types 9 OC43, 229E, HKU1, and NL63.

In total, 993 HCoV infections were identified over 8 years, with OC43 most commonly 12 seen and 229E the least. HCoVs were detected in a limited time period, between 13 December and April/May, and peaked in January/February. Highest infection frequency 14 was in children <5 years (18 per 100 person-years), with little variation in older age 15 groups (range: 7 to 11 per 100 person-years). Overall, 9% of adult cases and 20% of 16 cases in children were associated with medical consultation. Of the 993 infections, 260 17 were acquired from an infected household contact. The serial interval between index 18 and household-acquired cases ranged from 3.2 to 3.6 days and the secondary infection 19 risk ranged from 7.2% to 12.6% by type. 20 A c c e p t e d M a n u s c r i p t CONCLUSIONS 21
Coronaviruses are sharply seasonal. They appear, based on serial interval and 22

body_text.text: secondary infection risk, to have similar transmission potential to influenza A(H3N2) in 23 the same population. 24 A c c e p t e d M a n u s c r i p t Coronaviruses, long known to infect a wide variety of species, have been recognized as 25 human respiratory pathogens for more than 60 years. [1] [2] [3] While animal coronaviruses 26 have been associated with severe disease in their respective hosts, human 27 coronaviruses (HCoV) were historically detected in mild respiratory illnesses. 4-6 28 Therefore, the identification of Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) as caused 29 by a coronavirus of animal origin in 2002 was a surprise because of its epidemic 30 behavior as well as its severity. 7, 8 Also a surprise was ultimate interruption of SARS 31 transmission by public health measures. 9 In 2012, another novel coronavirus of animal 32 origin emerged as the causative agent of Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS). 10

Unlike SARS, human-to-human transmission of MERS has been limited and sporadic 34 cases have continued to occur primarily in Saudi Arabia among those with contact with 35 camels. 11 The current outbreak of a novel coronavirus (SARS-CoV-2) has focused 36 attention back to this often forgotten and unstudied group of pathogens. 12

HCoVs were first recognized when specimens from individuals ill with respiratory 38 illnesses were inoculated into organ cultures. One of these viruses is now known as OC 39 (organ culture) 43. 13 Another virus, 229E was first grown in primary human kidney 40 culture. 14 Because of the difficulties in isolating them, much of the initial work in 41 understanding their occurrence in was done by serology. 15, 16 Following renewed interest 42 after the SARS epidemic, two additional coronaviruses, HKU1 and NL63, were identified 43 in the 2000's, first from persons with severe respiratory illnesses. 17-20 44 Availability of reverse-transcriptase polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) has now made 45 it possible to detect infection easily for each of the 4 known human coronaviruses. 46 However, as data from population-based studies using molecular methods have A c c e p t e d M a n u s c r i p t accumulated, minimal attention has been paid to these viruses, perhaps because there HCoV type involved in coincident detection was also included in type-specific analyses.

Type-specific coronavirus incidence and corresponding 95% confidence intervals were 103 calculated by age group (<5, 6-11, 12-17, 18-49, and ≥50 years) and by study year. Age-adjusted multinomial logistic regression models were then used to compare the 128 odds of being assigned to each latent class between the four HCoV types.
Characteristics of the study population 131 The number of individuals under study ranged from 895 to 1441, and the number of 132 households ranged from 209 to 340 over the 8 years (Table 1)

The number of ARIs reported also varied from year to year, mainly related to the 139 number of individuals on report but also the differential occurrence of influenza and 140 other respiratory viruses (Table 1) person-years was relatively low and did not vary by age, the incidence was consistently 166 highest among children less than 5 years (Figure 3 ). Among those older than 5 years, 167 incidence was relatively flat with little consistent variation with increase in age. a n u s c r i p t illnesses in children less than 5 years and adults older than 50 years were most likely to 180 be classified as severe. In age-adjusted multinomial regression models (Table 2) (Table 3) . has most frequently infected adults to date. 30 Whether the relative sparing of children 236 has largely been driven by contact and exposure patterns or other factors remains 237 unclear. However, the frequency of infection in adults suggests that there is likely little 238 cross-protective immunity from prior seasonal HCoV infection.

The MERS coronavirus is limited in its potential for human to human transmission 240 except in the nosocomial setting. 11 Although the SARS coronavirus more effectively 241 transmitted human to human, transmission was interrupted by public health 242 interventions. 31 The seasonal HCoV viruses are clearly different in their transmission 243 characteristics given their continued seasonal circulation year after year. The serial 244 interval between cases and the secondary infection risk in the HIVE cohort was similar 245 to that previously found for A(H3N2). 32 Our secondary attack rates may reflect the 246 smaller household structure found in our region. A longitudinal study in Kenya found 247 M a n u s c r i p t overall attack rates as high as 34.0% over one season in a study of households of sizes 248 ranging to 37 members. 33

The transition from pandemic to seasonal circulation is well established for influenza, 250 wherein, following an influenza pandemic, the novel virus becomes the new seasonal 251 virus, replacing the previous A subtype. 34 The four current HCoVs have been circulating 252 for decades, and it is unclear how they initially emerged or whether they replaced 253 previously circulating viruses. 35

FIGREF0.text: children in the Ann Arbor, Michigan area that has been ongoing since 51 2010. Here we report on the occurrence of the 4 HCoV types over an 8 year period. complete methods of the HIVE cohort have been published previously. 21 55 Households were recruited from local households receiving primary care from the 56 University of Michigan Health Care System. From 2010-2011 through 2015-2016, 57 eligible households were those with 4 or more members at least 2 of whom were less 58 than 18 years old. In subsequent years, eligible households contained 3 or more 59 members including at least one child under 5 years (2016-2017) or under 10 years 60 (2017-2018). Each year in the spring or summer, households attended an enrollment or 61 re-engagement visit to collect or update the demographic characteristics for each 62 participant and household. Adult household members provided informed consent for 63 themselves and their children, and children 7 years or older also provided verbal assent 64 prior to participating. This study was reviewed and approved by the institutional review 65 board at the University of Michigan Medical School.

FIGREF1.text: participants were instructed to report the onset of two or more acute respiratory 68 illness (ARI) symptoms from anyone in the household, including: cough, fever or congestion, chills, headache, body aches, or sore throat. Weekly70 email and phone contacts were used to confirm the presence or absence of ARI in the 71 household. Beginning in 2014-2015 a separate set of age-specific symptom qualifiers 72 were provided for participants under 3 years of age, including: cough, 73 fever/feverishness, nasal congestion, trouble breathing, fussiness, decreased appetite, 74 and fatigue. Ill participants with 2 or more of the above symptoms attended an illness 75 visit within 7 days of illness onset where study staff interviewed them about their illness 76 and collected nasal and throat swabs (nasal only in children <3 years) combined in a 77 single vial of viral transport media. Study staff followed up with ill participants 78 approximately a week after their illness visit to collect additional information about the 79 course of the illness including participant report of whether they contacted a healthcare 80 provider regarding their illness.

FIGREF2.text: Prior to the 2014-15 season, HIVE ARI surveillance periods were seasonal based on 82 the likely influenza season. For the first 4 study years, the annual surveillance periods 83 were October 1, 2010 through April 30, 2011; December 1, 2011 through May 10, 2012; 84 October 1, 2012 through May 13, 2013; and October 1, 2013 through April 30, 2014. 85 Surveillance resumed on October 1, 2014 and has been operating year-round since 86 then. New surveillance years are designated beginning July 1 and lasting until June 30 87 of the subsequent year.

FIGREF3.text: collected at illness visits were tested for detection of respiratory90    viruses, including the four seasonal coronavirus types (229E, OC43, HKU1, and NL63).

FIGREF4.text: counts of HCoV 229E, HKU1, NL63, and OC43 were used to assess 98 annual patterning of each type; counts were also summed by month across all seasons 99 combined to assess broad seasonality by type. Illnesses with multiple, coincident HCoV 100 detections were only counted once in analyses of overall HCoV infections, but each 101

FIGREF5.text: 104Incidence was calculated as the number of type-specific coronavirus infections divided 105 by the total participant-time included during a specified time period. Because the 106 majority of the HCoV season was captured even in study years without year-round 107 surveillance, all participants were treated as contributing a full year of person time for 108 each study year in which they were enrolled.109For each study year, we defined household index cases as the first person in a110 household to develop ARI with HCoV detection. Secondary cases were defined as 111 those who developed ARI with HCoV detection within 14 days following illness in a 112 household contact with the same type. The serial interval was calculated as the average days from the illness onset a household index case to the illness onset of 114 secondary cases. Secondary infection risks were calculated as the proportion of 115 household contacts exposed to an index case who developed secondary infection. For 116 the purpose of these transmission analyses, only the first introduction of HCoV to a 117 household were considered. 118 We used latent class analysis to identify and compare classes of illness severity of 119 HCoV infection across age groups and the four HCoV types (Supplementary Materials).

FIGREF6.text: the latent items, we identified seven participant-reported potential markers of illness 121 severity including illness symptoms (cough, fever, fatigue, wheezing, and dyspnea), 122 missed work or school, and medically-attended illness (phone consultation, outpatient 123 care, and inpatient care). A priori, we anticipated three latent classes of severity to 124 represent mild, moderate, and severe illness; model diagnostics also confirmed that a 125 three-class model was most parsimonious. Latent class groups were then assigned to 126 each HCoV infection, not including cases with multiple coincident HCoV types detected.

FIGREF8.text: . Because of the 133 requirement that children be present in the household, the studied population tended to 134 be young, with relative absence of older adults. The numbers in the cohort varied from

FIGREF9.text: . Overall, from 2010-11 through 2017-18, 7992 ARI 141 cases were reported to HIVE; 7469 had an illness visit with specimen collection and 142 were tested for respiratory virus detection (93%). The proportion of ARIs associated 143 with coronavirus identification varied between 8.3% during the major influenza year 144 2014-2015 to 16.3% in 2012-2013. Co-detection of multiple coronavirus types ranged 145 from 0.7% of all coronavirus ARIs in 2010-2011 to 14.2% in 2014-2015. 146 Variation in identifying the four coronaviruses by seasons and years. 147 There was distinct seasonality in the identifications of the viruses. In the first 5 of the 8 148 years, no surveillance was conducted from June to September. When year-round 149 surveillance was in place in the 2015-2016 through 2017-2018 study years, only 9 150 (2.5%) of the total 364 coronavirus-associated ARI occurred from June through 151 September. Combined over the 8 years, the number of identifications for each virus 152 increased in December, peaked in January or February, and began to decrease in 153 March (Figure 1). The seasonal similarity between the 4 types is striking, with only the 154 peak aggregate month differing between January and February. 155 Identification of each of the four coronaviruses types occurred in each of the 8 study 156 years, except for 2016-17, when no HKU1 viruses were identified(Table 1, major years followed by lesser years. Such a pattern appears to be present 159 for all types where relatively high incidence is not seen in consecutive years for a 160 specific type. Likewise, combinations of co-circulating types were not found to be 161 consistent from year to year.

FIGREF10.text: Occurrence of infections by age and illness characteristics163 Infection rates for common respiratory pathogens are highest in young children and 164 usually fall off with increasing age. With the exception of 229E, where incidence per 100 165

FIGREF11.text: 9% of adult cases and 20% of cases in children were associated with medical 170 consultation. However, medical consultation only captures one facet of overall illness 171 severity. Therefore, we used latent class analysis to categorize coronavirus case 172 severity based on participant-reported symptoms and actions taken during the course of 173 their illness (Supplemental Materials). Mild illnesses were primarily characterized by 174 cough and fatigue, those with moderate illnesses were additionally likely to have fever 175 and to miss school or work, and those with severe illness additionally were likely to have 176 wheezing, dyspnea, or to seek care for their illness. Of all single coronavirus detections, 177 59% were categorized as mild illness by latent class methods. Moderate and severe 178 illness were noted in 31% and 10% of coronavirus detections, respectively. HCoV

FIGREF13.text: an ideal setting for determining the transmission characteristics of 187 respiratory viruses. Of the 993 HCoVs identified, 260 occurred within 14 days of 188 exposure to a household contact infected with the same type. The secondary attack risk 189 was 7.2% for 229E, 8.6% for HKU1, 10.6% for OC43, and 12.6% for NL63. The average 190 serial interval between the onset of illness in the household index case and onset of 191 illness in secondary cases was similar across (3.2 days for NL63 and HKU1, 3.3 days 192 for OC43, and 3.6 days for 229E). Consistent with overall patterns of incidence by age 193 (Figure 3), index cases were most frequently children with the exception of 229E where 194 adults 18 to 49 years were responsible for nearly half of the household introductions195

FIGREF14.text: have been recognized for many years to be a cause of common 198 respiratory illnesses, documentation of their involvement has lagged behind that of other 199 agents, such as the rhinoviruses. This includes frequency of infection, illnesses 200 produced and transmission characteristics. We might not even know about the the two most recently identified viruses, NL63 and HKU1, if attention had 202 not been directed to HCoV following the occurrence of SARS. The development of the 203 RT-PCR test and the inclusion of the 4 types of HCoV in multiplex clinical testing 204 panels, mainly used in handling severe illnesses such as pneumonia, have resulted in 205 numerous reports of the involvement of these viruses in hospitalizations. While studies 206 of hospitalized patients have established the role of HCoV in causing lower respiratory 207 illness and the global circulation of these viruses, they are unable to shed light on the 208 frequency or seasonality of these viruses in the broader community. There are a few 209 exceptions which have followed HCoV infections over longer periods often in special 210 population groups. In particular, a recent study covered 9 years of Norwegian children 211 hospitalized with respiratory infection and found that coronaviruses were involved in 212 9.1% of episodes. 26 The highest frequencies were in young children, similar to the 213 infection rates demonstrated in the current study and also identical to it was the ordering 214 of frequency of types involved with OC43 the most common and 229E the least. While 215 the authors did not emphasize seasonality, it was clear that most of the infections 216 occurred in the winter months. 217 The regular appearance of all types of coronaviruses in the same months with minimal 218 circulation in the summer was a clear finding of this study. Unlike the influenza viruses 219 which peak at different times during the colder season from year to year and even the 220 rhinoviruses which are most common in the autumn and spring but are present year 221 round, the coronaviruses are sharply seasonal with little spread after May until 222 November or December. Our findings, on a larger scale, expand on the results a two 223year study in childcare attendees suggesting a similar seasonal pattern.27 It is of interest SARS coronavirus outbreaks occurred during the same time period, with the 225 end of global outbreaks in the period of May-June 2003.28 Whether such a time table 226applies to the current circulation of SARS-CoV-2 is impossible to determine at this time.227Another notable finding in this community study was the fact that, in those above 4228 years of age, HCoV infection rates were relatively consistent. Most agents causing 229 lower respiratory infections typically have falling incidence with increasing age, 230 sometimes with an increase in young adults. 29 However, it is clear that like other 231 respiratory viruses, HCoV infect people of all ages and infection only produces relative 232 immunity. The type-specificity of the protection is also not completely clear; although 233 frequent co-circulation of types and co-detection within individuals suggests that 234 protection is likely not highly cross-reactive. As with SARS and MERS, SARS-CoV-2 235

FIGREF15.text: Contrary to influenza, MERS and SARS, have not 254 become a fixed presence in seasonal respiratory illness circulation on a global scale.

FIGREF16.text: Only time will tell if SARS-CoV-2 will become a continuing presence in the seasonal256    HCoV landscape, continue with limited circulation as with MERS, or like SARS, 257 disappear from humans altogether.
